newsitem.title: UK: British opposition calls for tougher sleaze probe.
newsitem.headline: British opposition calls for tougher sleaze probe.

text.p: Britain's main opposition parties increased pressure on the government on Monday for an independent inquiry into allegations of parliamentary sleaze involving a former minister.
Labour and the minority Liberal Democrats claim a parliamentary watchdog set up after a wave of sleaze scandals does not have sufficient powers for an in-depth inquiry.
They are also concerned about allegations that ruling Conservative party managers sought to influence a key committee which governs the conduct of members of parliament.
The move, which comes the day parliament resumes after the summer break, was designed to keep up pressure on the government in the run-up to an election now no more than seven months away.
It was given extra weight by the weekend decision of a Conservative rebel MP, Peter Thurnham, to join the Liberal Democrats in protest at Prime Minister John Major's handling of the sleaze row.
Donald Dewar, Labour's senior parliamentary manager, said: "What we're trying to do here...is to get a comprehensive examination which is designed to allay public fears."
But senior Conservative MPs were outraged by the move, which they said was motivated by a desire to score political points off the government and not a concern for ethics.
Conservative MP Paul Marland told the BBC: "I'm astonished that the Labour party and the Liberals are actually taking this issue up again...It doesn't do parliament any good.
The new outbreak of conflict follow successful annual party conferences for both Labour and the Conservatives.
Major managed to pull his party together and give an image of unity at his conference last week, portraying himself as an honest, down-to-earth leader.
But Labour, whose disciplined party conference boosted their already huge opinion poll lead, believes the ruling party is vulnerable to charges of sleaze after 17 years in office.
Major has a parliamentary majority of just two. Although it is unlikely Major could be brought down over the current argument, a call for a vote of no confidence could be damaging.
Labour leader Tony Blair, on a tour of South Africa, on Sunday left the option open. "We will have to wait and see how the debate progresses. I don't rule anything out," he said.
The latest case involves allegations that former trade minister Neil Hamilton accepted cash in return for asking parliamentary questions in breaches of House of Commons rules.

Hamilton has denied the charges. But two weeks ago he dropped a libel action against the Guardian newspaper which broke the story. Hamilton said he could not afford the legal fees, but the Guardian responded by printing fresh allegations.

The new allegations are to be investigated by Sir Gordon Downey, the so-called Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards -- a post set up after a full-scale inquiry last year sparked by the original charges which led to a tightening up of rules.
But Dewar said he believed Downey's current powers would not allow him to investigate all the new allegations.

They also want him to investigate charges a Conservative party manager, David Willetts, wrote to ruling party MPs on the key House of Commons privileges committee suggesting they use their majority to ensure Hamilton was cleared.
